subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
msgSnippet: http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?MethodsShouldBePublic For some debate. I agree, by the way.  Test First means that very few of my methods are private, and I really
messageBody:
http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?MethodsShouldBePublic

For some debate.

I agree, by the way. Test First means that very few of my methods are
private, and I really don't see this as a bad thing. (Most of the ones that
are private are there only because that's what Eclipses' Extract Method
refactoring does).

NB: That is not the same as making private methods public for testing
purposes. That should be avoided at all

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chirag Shashikant Doshi [mailto:chirag.doshi@...]
> Sent: 16 October 2003 04:02
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
>
>
> Hi Michael
>
> >> Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather make
> evrything
> public and testable and expose real APIs via Java Interfaces.
>
> I don't understand what exactly you mean by this, please
> elaborate or could you lead me to a place where I can see
> some examples of the above.
>
> Thanks
> Chirag
>
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Michael Silverstein [mailto:msilverstein@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, October 15, 2003 11:07 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [junit] Re: How to test private methods, its urgent
>
>
>
> > -----Original Message-----
> > From: Dave Astels [mailto:dave@...]
> > Private methods support public methods. Therefore well
> tested public
> > methods will include the behaviour of the private methods.
> >
> > There is no real reason for directly testing private methods.
> >
>
> Domain objects support the GUI. By the logic above a well
> tested GUI will include the behavior of the domain objects,
> so there is no reason to unit test the domain objects :-)
>
> I've occasionally found reason to write unit tests for
> private, supporting methods. Often you loose efficiency
> testing supporting methods indirectly via their caller - such
> as in the case where you want to test their ability to
> properly handle a range of input values.
>
> Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather
> make everything public and testable and expose real APIs via
> Java Interfaces.
>
> To answer the original poster: google junit + "private methods"
